title.narrative: Emergency health assistance to earthquake victims in Southwestern Haiti

description.narrative:
The most urgent needs identified by national health authorities include: surge medical personnel, both general practitioners and specialists; rapid procurement of medicines and medical supplies for trauma care and other essential health needs; procurement of tents, tarps and generators for damaged facilities; logistics and operational support for the delivery of materials, deployment of response teams, and transfer of patients; financial and logistic resources to carry out operation on COVID-19, WASH, vector control, mental health and psychosocial care in short and medium term. With these CERF funds, WHO support immediate lifesaving engagements to address the acute growing health needs in the most affected areas and reduce the risk of diseases outbreak and further deterioration of the health status of vulnerable individuals, starting with pregnant women, children and the elderly. Priority engagements focus on supporting the provision of emergency medical supplies to ensure emergency care and ensuring patients can access critical health services, including emergency services and psychosocial support.
This project targets a total of 46,360 affected people with its Health engagement.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Emergency health assistance to earthquake victims in Southwestern Haiti

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS HAITI RAPID RESPONSE EARTHQUAKE 2021

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: Children, girls, adolescents, men and women living in areas affected by the earthquake and in need of urgent medical care are provided with timely emergency care assistance

CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation (community health agents sensitized about mental health consequences of disasters and trained to provide psychologist first aid)
H.7 Number of functional health facilities supported (Number of damaged health facilities benefitting from rapid repairs)
H.7 Number of functional health facilities supported (health facilities receiving medicines, medical and health supplies )
Number of victims attended by local health facilities or medically evacuated by the CAN to a functioning health facility (at least 80% of injured people)
Disease surveillance and outbreak control interventions intensified to prevent transmission of epidemic-prone diseases in affected areas
Number of displaced people with COVID-19 symptoms in shelters that were sampled
Number of epidemic alerts with a completed field investigation
Number of individuals in shelters or temporary settlement camps with diarrheal disease who are sampled in the 6 months project at the community level
